firstChapter.htmlHeader: Domestic violence and abuse: Summary
firstChapter.htmlStringContent:
• Domestic violence and abuse is defined as any incident or pattern of incidents of controlling, coercive or threatening behaviour, violence, or abuse between people aged 16 years or over who are, or have been, intimate partners or are family members regardless of gender or sexuality. It includes psychological, physical, sexual, emotional, and financial abuse, forced marriage, and 'honour'-based violence.
  • At least 29.9% of women and 17% of men in England and Wales have experienced domestic abuse at some point in their lives. 
  • Risk factors for experiencing domestic violence and abuse include being female; having a long-term illness, disability, or mental health problem; and pregnancy or childbirth.
  • Domestic violence and abuse can adversely affect the physical and mental health of the person being abused and that of any children in their care.
  • Signs of possible domestic violence and abuse include unexplained injuries, depression, fear, alcohol or drug misuse, and the presence of an intrusive ‘other person’ in consultations.
  • Healthcare services should have a domestic violence and abuse policy and a designated person responsible for the response to domestic violence and abuse. Healthcare staff should be trained on how to recognize the possible signs, how to enquire sensitively and safely, the importance of confidentiality, and the organization’s process for responding to disclosure. 
  • Management of suspected domestic violence and abuse includes:
    • Facilitating disclosure in private. If an interpreter is needed, a professional interpreter should be used.
    • Reassuring the person that the discussion is confidential and that information provided will be shared only with their consent, except in exceptional circumstances (for example, if there is a risk of significant harm to a child).
    • Advising people who are reluctant to disclose the abuse that they can do this when they are ready and that specialist support services are available.
    • Providing information on support groups.
    • Keeping a detailed and accurate record of the consultation, including any actions taken.
  • Management of disclosed domestic violence and abuse includes: 
    • Affirming that the person has made an important step by disclosing and reiterating the advice on confidentiality.
    • Assessing the person for any physical injuries or mental health conditions and managing these appropriately.
    • Working with the designated person for domestic violence and abuse to assess whether the person and/or any children are in immediate danger, to inform a safe plan of management and referrals to specialist support services.
    • Supporting children who are affected by domestic violence and abuse.
    • Providing information on support groups.
    • Keeping a detailed and accurate record of the consultation, including any actions taken.
    • Providing continuing support for the person.
    • Managing people who disclose that they are perpetrating domestic violence and abuse.
  • If it is deemed necessary to share information with other agencies, consent should be sought. If a decision is made to share information without consent or if consent is refused, the healthcare professional should:
    • Be completely sure that the decision does not place someone at risk of greater violence.
    • Consider seeking expert advice, for example, from the Caldicott Guardian.
